summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered final judgments against Georgia Gulf Lake Charles, LLC and Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, jointly, severally and in solido, for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in New Orleans, alleges that Georgia Gulf improperly awarded Mr. Adams supplemental earnings benefits (SEB) for his hearing loss.  According to the complaint, Adams began to notice some degree of hearing loss in his left ear in the mid-1980s but did not seek SEB until he was sixty-five years old.  He also allegedly had a habit of repeatedly removing his right earplug over the years to converse with his co-workers in the plant environment.  In addition, the complaint alleges that, in December 2011, Georgia Gulf terminated its contract with Adams, despite Georgia Gulf's repeated requests for him to reapply for SEB.  Georgia Gulf agreed to pay $5,000.00 in penalties and attorney fees for the work done on this matter.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC's Complaint, the defendants consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins Georgia Gulf from violating these provisions, and orders Georgia Gulf to pay a civil penalty of $7,500.00. The settlement is subject to court approval.  On May 9, 2017, the SEC filed a complaint in the United States District Court in the Eastern District of Louisiana, alleging that, among other things, that Adams had suffered an occupational hearing loss during his employment with Georgia Gulf, and that he had sought employment since his retirement in June 2011, but was unable to afford to pay SEB at the time of his alleged hearing loss because he was disabled from working as a result of his job loss. The SEC also charged Georgia Gulf with acting as an unregistered broker-dealer in connection with the alleged loss of hearing in Adams' right ear. Georgia Gulf has agreed to settle the case against it by consenting to a judgment permanently enjoining it from future violations of the federal securities laws, ordering it to pay civil penalties of $8,000 and $25,000, respectively, for each of those violations, and imposing an injunction against further violations of Section 15(a)(1) and 15(b)(2)(A) and (c).  The complaint also seeks a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and civil penalties.
